content:
Yes, certain skills could be particularly important in landing an undergraduate research position in computer science and engineering at the University of Alberta. Here are some of them: 

1. Strong programming skills - most research projects in computer science and engineering require strong programming skills in a variety of languages, such as C++, Python, Java, or MATLAB. Make sure that you are proficient in at least one programming language and can quickly learn new ones. 

2. Analytical skills - research projects may require you to work with large data sets, algorithms, or complicated models. Having strong analytical skills could help you to identify patterns and trends in the data or help you to synthesize complex ideas.

3. Teamwork and collaboration - research projects often consist of a team of researchers working together toward a common goal. Being able to work effectively with others, communicate well, and contribute to the team can make you stand out as a strong candidate.

4. Time management and organization - research projects can be complex and require a good deal of planning and coordination. Being able to manage your workload, meet deadlines, and stay organized could help you to be successful in the position.

5. Research experience - if you have relevant research experience in computer science and engineering, it can definitely improve your chances of being selected as an undergraduate researcher.

6. High academic standing - having a good GPA can demonstrate your ability to handle rigorous academic work and provide evidence of your commitment to learning.

These are just some of the skills that can be important when applying for an undergraduate research position in computer science and engineering at the University of Alberta.
